commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. March V.I.P.s?: Abbr.  (4)
2. ___ for sore eyes (www.optometrists.com?)  (4)
3. Mars with bars  (5)
4. Those whose time has come and gone?  (2)-(4)
5. Liver spot?  (5)


SGTS
SITE
BRUNO
EX-CONS
ABODE
Just had to chime in here with a comment that will occur to just about; namely, that this Monday puzzle was nothing to sneeze at.

My goodness. If your sneezes sound like that, please see a doctor 😆

Fun puzzle!
Man that theme is great. 😂
I hope 36 across doesn’t get you in trouble with President Trump.
I done did this puzz
Such a fun Monday puzzle and theme - I had to work to get those crosses because I definitely don’t know how to spell the revealer!
Fun theme, but I didn't get it until I was looking back at the crossword after solving. Noticing the AH, AH, AHCHOO was definitely a lightbulb moment for me.
It's not Choo baby, it's Smee...
I'm_so_glad_I_am one: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fqSUm-x9Mug
Tricky clues link is broken again.
This is one of the cutest Monday themes in a while! Great puzzle overall. Thanks!

Said one handkerchief to another, "Sneezed to meet you!"

(Everybody nose that pun already.)
Not a Monday puzzle.  Too many obscure clues for Monday.  Definitely a Tuesday.
Aw shucks, if that wasn't the most adorable little theme I ever...!

Thoroughly enjoyed this theme and puzzle. My favorite stage production in hs was Peter Pan. Like a puzzle where Denali and Dog team are in the same puzzle. Trump is in Denial over Denali. I’ve seen all the comments that this is more a Tuesday but I disagree. The chewier clues had lots of easy fill in my opinion making it a delightful ah, ah, CHOO (I’ve been known to scare people with my sneezes) theme.

Forgot my favorite pun. If you get offended easily at religious puns please skip. However this was hung up in my priest’s office.
A picture of a kid dragging a string with a wadded up Kleenex on it and a sign post pointing to hell off the page. Titled: lead a snot into temptation. (And lead us not…..). I still can’t say the Lord’s Prayer with a straight face

I was especially pleased at 36A

L
18D was dirty, especially if you don't speak Spanish to get 20A. I had INK in there to the end.
Mt. McKinley no more.

Plodding Mondays are the pits.  What a pleasure to find that this one definitely was not. Put me in a good MOOD!  I didn't even mind that my first fill BA t MITZVAH was wrong, because JIMMY was a CHOO-in.  

A lively and interesting puzzle, Mr. van Geel.  Pretty much the EPITOME of a Monday winner—a SUREBET we'll see you again. I don't think I'm BIASED when I say I hope it's soon.

OHWELL

If only every solve
was as swift  -
a light shift from Sunday
to the realities of Monday
a sweet little repast that
 jiggles a few words from
this old solver's feed bag, and signals, 
"Giddyup - here's a new week of grids to wrassle!"
Just found out I didn’t know how to spell GESUNDHEIT. 🤣

6d a Madmen throwback. 
A regular solve wasn’t as easy to spot with today’s top story clue at 14a. 
And a clash hit, good clean fun and no wailing for today’s holiday Monday.

The Sharif don’t like it
You know he really hates it
Rockin’ the … Denali
A fun puzzle indeed!! A cute gimmick, yet very fair and straightforward. Also, timely with all the pollen in the Air!  🤧

Fun and fast — xwstats tells me it’s my second fastest Monday. Though I could easily picture SARAH Silverman, I inexplicably remembered her name as Susan. That might have cost me a new personal best. I like many of the longer Down words, such as APPEASE, EPITOME (which I long thought was pronounced like the EPI- of “epidermis” and a word that means a large and heavy book), NEMESIS and ARMOIRE. That’s some fresh fill. I also liked being reminded of “Rock THE CASBAH.” It’s not the Clash’s best song, but I have always liked it. Many of the locations in the video for the song were within a few miles of my house in Austin, so watching it is a trip back to the long-gone Austin of my college years. https://youtu.be/bJ9r8LMU9bQ?si=DOnSraGY2wcw5sP_ Thanks, Mr. van Geel!
There are so many car models it might be possible to construct a crossword puzzle with every clue solving to a car model name or make.
Lots of freshness in this puzzle which I enjoyed more than any other Monday puzzle this year. Thanks, Thomas!
I'm assuming the NYT will be dis-incorporated by regal decree over 36A.

Regarding JIMMYCHOO.

I got it by crosses and logical guesses.  I swear I'd never heard of it before.

And then, about an hour after the puzzle, I'm re-watching "The Sopranos" season 3, and Christopher walks in with a whole bag full of Jimmy Choo's.

I've seen that episode at least six times, and it never once made an impression on me.

I think my brain completely shuts down when anything involving fashion comes along.

Constructors, I enjoyed your puzzle.
Much more fun than a regular Mon puzzle, the theme made me chuckle

First: what’s with the new layout? It took me 10 minutes to find out where I can type my comment.

Ok, on to the grid; a cute and breezy offering. Love that the Clash get a mention.

APACHES used to regularly fly over our last house, as we lived near an army base (helicopter wing). I was also used as target practice when walking the dog in the fields; the peace and quiet would be shattered by the distinctive whup whup of the blades. I’d look up to find a helicopter on either side of me, low enough to see the pilots waving. Thanks guys.

I dream of owning a pair of shoes as pretty as JIMMY CHOO makes them. Alas, they won’t fit in with my country lifestyle and I don’t think he makes wellies. Ah well.

I have no idea if this will post, as it’s in a new and weird format. Here goes…
Loved it! I almost never bother with the Monday or Tuesday but this one was not mind-numbingly easy. Fun, intelligent cluing and no junk. In fact I didn't even finish it! I don't know from cars ...

Lovely crossword. Funny, clever theme.
The NW was tricky for me; fortunately I knew BARMITZVAH other wise UTZ would have been impossible.

GESUNDHEIT is not much used in UK;  people used to say, 'Bless you' but not so much now. With two small grandsons it's usually "Don't use your sleeve!"

For me, US English is inventive and ingenious, but HONEY DO ....
Gruesome.

Now even the Mondays are getting difficult for me, but I’m not complaining as I know the majority would like that.  

I especially enjoyed the constructors notes today, and look forward to more puzzles from Thomas.

Fun Monday puzzle. Didn't tumble to the trick until I was almost done and stopped and pondered. That was just a great touch. Unusual puzzle find today - a Thursday from July 7, 2011 by Caleb Rasmussen. Don't recall seeing another like this - a bit hard to describe. The 'reveal' was: "Traffic sign literally violated 12 times in this puzzle" NOUTURN Except that answer actually appeared as: NOU ___T ___URN And all the other theme answers 'turned' down on a U. You have to go look at it to get it. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/7/2011&g=44&d=A I'm done. ....

Very cute theme.  

Nicely done, Thomas.

I'll admit that I was a little puzzled for a second about VAH, BAH, TAH......until I got to HOO. 

Seemed appropriate when I thought "AHh CHOO!".
I love a funny theme on a Monday! Made me laugh out loud - what a fun solve!!

Perfect mood for a Monday morning.

My Swedish mother would say
“Prosit!” when we sneezed.
(Pronounced PROOZ- it)

In 4th grade, someone sneezed 
and I said “Prosit!”

What?
Prosit?
Why did you say that?
Because you sneezed!
What did you say?
Prosit.
Why?
You sneezed!
But…why would you say that?
You. Sneezed.

Got home and had to explain to 
min mamma that she should give us
a heads-up when we’re speaking Swedish.

Swinglish was confusing.

Thank you Thomas!
Do I take it there's no lead pipe in Clue, as there is in Cluedo in the UK?
This puzzle was soooooo good looking.

So, I was smiling inside as I filled this in.  Why?
•	Gorgeous-to-fill-in answers (EPITOME, NEMESIS, ARMOIRE, APPEASE).
•	Fun-to-say-out-loud answers (ANDALE, GESUNDHEIT, MAHI, CHIC, UTZ, TABASCO, CASBAH).
•	Names with spark (JIMMY CHOO, DOJA CAT).

Then, when the theme hit me – this chutzpah theme that could have either landed or thudded – I laughed aloud.  

When anyone buoys my mood, I get happy, yes, and always wedded to that happiness is gratitude. A mighty thank you, Thomas, for turning this box of letters into a marvelous day brightener!

clever theme, fun solve. 
some will consider this a nitpick, I suppose, but only a mother can “have” a bar/bat/bas mitzvah. rather, it’s something one becomes.

DENALI forever.

The HONEY-DO phrase has always grated on my ear. So twee. Probably doesn't help that I don't like the melon.

ANDALE! Heading back up to the wilds of Jersey today, will be off-line for a week or so. Keep puzzling, friends.

This puzzle was nothing to sneeze at.
I must have missed the column: Crossword Rappers to Commit to Memory. 
20A. From my Spanish 101 days, I jumped on VAMOS. 
How many of us can still recite the whole dialog?
Repeatan:
"Hola Isabel, como estas? Estoy bien gracias, y tu...

¡Feliz Lunes!

Is there something wrong with the app? Finished the crossword this morning and got my time. Opened to do spelling bee and my crossword is now showing as incomplete. Have checked every letter against the answer key and all correct. 

Don't let me lose my streak NYT!!

I love when a Monday puzzle has aspirations for a Tuesday. I'm always in favour of upward mobility. 

You go, Monday. Don't stop believin'! ANDALE.
[Sad] Prediction:  Within four years, Denali will be known on Google Maps as Mount Trump.
Curiously, shouldn't the answer for the clue "Contents of a sleeve" be ARMS instead of ARM since the clue is plural?
Fun riddle!  Thank you for the chuckle!
Thanks to Louis Winthorpe III, I immediately knew the answer to 45D, La Bohème.

What a post Easter treat to find a sprightly Monday puzzle with a witty theme perfectly in keeping with the advent of allergy season here in the NE.  It makes me feel like I could rock THECASBAH.  

Special props for DENALI.  Small acts of rebellion are meaningful.

Dumb originally meant “lacking the power of speech” or “temporarily unable to speak.” People who could neither speak nor hear were labeled deaf and dumb or deaf-mute. From there, dumb developed a sense that means “lacking intelligence or good judgment; stupid; dull-witted.” As a result, the association with ignorance makes this word extremely offensive to people who are deaf or hard of hearing.

I'm never sure how to rate Monday puzzles, since I breeze through them (comparatively, of course). Usually I try to break my personal record for speed, and when I know I won't, I just finish up and move on.

So it's pretty noticeable when I enjoy the Monday theme enough to flat-out stop caring about my time. It was simple and silly, but it totally worked. What a fun little way to start the week!

From wikipedia:

"Amin's rule was characterized by rampant human rights abuses, including political repression, ethnic persecution, extrajudicial killings, as well as nepotism, corruption, and gross economic mismanagement."

Yeesh. Seems a little harsh for someone who was just trying to make Uganda great again.



(Email me when my comment is removed)

Yesterday's Comment in Chief never appeared; can't figure out why... But here I am to try again...  (Several responses did pass muster.maybe I need a new identity?  Too late!  I already carried MOL into the substack...)

AH, so relaxing to do a Monday puzzle...but what is more annoying than a sneeze that is a "hang-fire"?

Speakiing of MAGMA...Etna just erupted (again)...and there are dire predictions about Mt. St. Helen and even Mt Ranier.  Uh Oh.  

Speaking of shoes....after a certain age, you can wear cute shoes for about an hour, after which your feet hurt too much and no amount of sparkly CHIC fashion is worth it.  The End.

I adored this puzzle! Especially loved reading the theme and revealer out loud to my husband. What a hoot! And how perfect for allergy season!


('Scuze me. I need a tissue.)

Did not know 6D. 

 I know Intel, Nvidia, TSMC, Broadcom, Qualcomm, but not that one.  AMD didn't work.
So fun!  Went quickly, but I think I'll never break my best time due to fat fingers on the keyboard.  OH WELL (46D)

Lots of fun with this puzzle today!  Have to share that, coincidentally, I had a mini sneezing attack (North Jersey pollen is on the rise!)  as I was completing the grid, before I got to the revealer.  Made the a-ha moment (or AH-CHOO moment) that much sweeter, even as I was reaching for my tissues!  Happy Monday fellow solvers!

What a fun Monday puzzle, with a clever theme. I now do not look at the time it takes to do a puzzle. That makes it much more fun. (A recent Mini which took 2 minutes was an outlier. I hope.)

Hats off to the constructor! More from  him, please.
I had no (t)issues with this puzzle! :)
This did not feel like a Monday puzzle at all! Felt too tricky and had too many clues I had no knowledge about :(
Happily high-protein for a Monday! Great way to start off the week.
And enjoy it I did -- thank you Thomas!
Fun Monday with a little more challenge than is typical. Took 5m53s. Thanks!

I really enjoyed the theme to this puzzle.  I did not get it until the revealer and afterwards did my own sneeze reading the AH AH AH CHOO in my head.  That was really nice.

What I enjoyed less about this puzzle was the construction.  I think it was a mistake to put blocks of 4 at the ends of the center row.  Not only did that segment the puzzle, but it made for tougher fill that was not as snazzy or interesting.  Stacks of 7 are tough to work with and usually not as lively.  With a center word at just 7 letters, you can eliminate 3 of the 4 blocks which gets rid of those stacks, and then you can have some fun, longer downs to boot.

Because of that choice in the center, this was a noticeably harder puzzle than a typical Monday.  Still a very fun concept that was a lot of fun (and that's what puzzles are all about anyways!).

When Russia owned Alaska, they called Mt McKinley Bolshaya Gora, which just means, "big mountain," which is pretty much what DENALI means. Just because a name is Native American doesn't make it special - they can't all be "Father of Waters."

(Ohio has more electoral votes than Alaska.)
Extra hint for # 32 Across- starts with, " Peoples Republic."
Fun puzzle!  Cute theme (appropriate fpr allergy season!) and a breezy solve. I'm surprised at the haters in the comments -- seemed like a perfect little Monday moment. Thanks!

Fun puzzle, fun theme. 

The revealer was a tricky spell for me…I thought I knew it but when the crosses weren’t coming to me right away I thought I had it wrong…this was an unexpectedly eye-opening Monday solve.

Mr. Van Geel, thank you so much for this delightful Monday puzzle. Sometimes Mondays are a little ho hum, finished too quickly, but this was such fun. Loved the theme, loved everything about it. I saw another recent comment noting that some folks were complaining about it. I can’t imagine why, and I’ve decided not to read any more of the comments (at least for now) and let it spoil my good mood. Instead I’ll go out for my daily four mile hike and enjoy the sunshine. I got the Wordle in 2 this morning, so I have to hang on to this joy for as long as I can. 
And Sam, as always, I loved your comments, your sense of humor, and your knack for finding great photos to illustrate the puzzle theme. 😊🙌🏻
Ah, it\s spring fever! (or allergeries)
utz and barmitzvah was tricky. Never heard of utz so i had it as uts and barmitsvah.

I imagine many of you are watching and enjoying the British show “Ludwig” these days. It’s about a crossword setter who is also great at solving tricky murders for the police. Check it out if you can.

Fun start to the solving week!! I loved the theme. I also love these oddly reassuring moments where I get a glimpse of a world completely beyond my sphere of existence and the ensuing relief that it's not one I inhabit: if someone asked me to HONEY-DO this or that, I would make like a melon and split.

Pessimist here, to point out that if you think [So it goes] implies OH WELL, you’re really getting your hopes up. But such is our BIASED language.

(Kidding. Mostly. And it *was* a good puzzle :)

Sometimes the puzzle seems like it’s just for me, does anyone else feel that way? Starting off with DENALI, then with MTV and the Clash and Barry Manilow and DOJA CAT, little reminders of childhood with Speedy Gonzalez and Peter Pan, and, to top it all off, BARMITZVAH and UTZ and GESUNDHEIT! L’chaim!
There are only three bases on a baseball diamond. Home is a plate.
SO close to beating my 4:08 best time ever with this one, except for a typo! Ah, well…

Uh Oh. I don't think this one will pass muster in the Oval Office. But then, I doubt if the NYT is a regular favorite at 1600 Pennsylvania these days, so it probably won't be noticed that Denali (shhh) was used. :)

Was trying to figure out what the proper response to something starting "VAH-BAH-TAH" could possibly be... something in a foreign language? It didn't help that I had ruled out JIMMY CHOO because I thought it was spelled CHU. Still managed to get there, just not as quickly as I might have. Fun Monday!

I spent a little too long wondering what languages sneeze in VAH, BAH, and TAH CHOO?! It was a fun mind journey and I looked forward to seeing what Sam had to say about it that would clarify the marvelous people who sneeze this way. 

D'oh! 

Talk about boneheaded!

Took a while to stop laughing at myself over that one!  

Really enjoyed the puzzle!  Looks like I finished a little slower than my average, but it felt very fast and fun. 

I'm currently on a road trip home from Easter with my husband and now I have to decide whether I should torture him the rest of the way home by singing COPA cabana or Rock the CASBAH at the top of my lungs. I'm not a good singer, but what I lack in talent, I more than make up for you enthusiasm. 

You know, there are enough hours left in the journey that I could just sing both to him. Yep, he's a lucky guy! 😂

Strands #414
“What talent!”
🔵🔵🔵💡
🔵🟡🔵🔵

Since Linda Jo is off in the Pine Barrens with Christopher and Paulie for a while, I'll post this.

No spoilers before View All Replies, please.

Fun puzzle.

Hit the sweet spot for a Monday (for me).

Coincidentally, I was asked just yesterday if I knew how to spell GESUNDHEIT! (Luckily for me, the answer was yes.)

Also...I grew up in south central Pennsylvania, so I'm well familiar with UTZ.
There’s no more Denali it’s called Mt. McKinley now

What an appropriate theme, considering I am suffering from allergies at the moment!

DENALI?  Let's get with the program -- McKinley! 😉

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

P.S. Will -- Is there an online version of “Will Shortz’s Wittiest, Wackiest Crosswords?"
What a charming little puzzle! I usually just speedrun Mondays as a way to wake my brain up for the week but I slowed down to enjoy this one. Lovely!
Got too depressed to puzzle for a minute. Monday seems like a good day to get back on the ship. Or the road to Denali if we can still call it that.

I only just noticed that Sam wrote that this puzzle is set in the ol’ factory.

😂😂😂😂😂😂😂

Love it!!!

This is a timely puzzle as I'm currently taking a sick day off work, sneezing and coughing up a storm.  At least my appendix surgery site has healed well enough that I don't have to worry about popping a stitch. 😄

This puzzle was a lot of fun and really cheered me up... thanks!

@Strudel Dad

… everyone

@Strudel Dad

Just like other dad jokes, there’s a little something left out of its first telling.

@Elizabeth Connors
Brilliant!

State is going to ignore Africa...
...and 59A shows up.

@Beth 
Good one!
You're in Denali Denial
Would someone please explain Barry's cryptic comment? I don't get it because I know Idi Amin is dead. Does "State" mean Secretary of State?

@JT I wouldn't presume to speak for Barry, but since he hasn't responded I will suggest that perhaps he's referring to a story in the NYT yesterday about a leaked draft executive order proposing a radical restructuring of theUS State Department in which almost all Africa operations will be eliminated. https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/20/us/politics/trump-state-department-overhaul.html In that context, perhaps his mention of 59A is a reminder of what can occur in countries outside of US influence. I would add, perhaps we should look inward as well.
@Captain Kidnap You are very good.
I was baffled as to why this had 95 recommended, until I read it aloud. Good one!
Patrick, Try this: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/20/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2025-04-21.html#link-4acaa460

@Mike

Come on. A pun like that is snot okay.

@Mike

I think you blew it.
/
/
/

@Mike
Sinus up for another week.

@Mike

I use to scough at these puns, but now I find I have a real hanky-ring for them.
@Mike 4 boogers for that one!

@Mike

My oh my, how do you manage always to amucous!

@Susan

I'm curious which clues were obscure. It's a genuine question. The only clue that made me pause for a few seconds was military choppers, but that filled in from the crosses.

@Andrzej
A to do list is a list of chores that need to get done. And a Honey do list is a list that you want your Honey (significant other, usually the male partner) to do.
Also a bit of a play on the Honeydew melon. 

ODIE  the dog shows up fairly frequently.

@Andrzej

Proper translation: "Honey, do this, honey, do that." People explaining this didn't make it clear because they already understood it.

@Teresa

Thanks 🙂
@Andrzej Also an inversion of the Carl Perkins song Honey Don't, perhaps best known on this side of the pond as Ringo's song on With The Beatles.

@Andrzej “[N]ot being familiar with Garfield means I lack proper context . . . .” You’re not missing much there. I never much cared for that strip. But to be fair, there aren’t many American comic strips that are truly funny. HONEY Can DO is a brand of shelving here that can be assembled without tools. I’m sure the name was chosen at a riff on the idea of a HONEY DO list. I’m a bit embarrassed by how much of that shelving we bought for our closets and garage, but our stuff has to go somewhere (and we have much less stuff than we did before we moved). This song doesn’t use HONEY DO, but the idea is the same: https://youtu.be/lvV6HQWuR-s?si=hSDjlOyr5NNJCmtf

@Eric Hougland

Comic strips in the American sense aren't really a thing here, especially serialized ones, with a recurring protagonist and cast of characters.

Polish newspapers and magazines often feature satyrical drawings, and some of their authors, like Andrzej Mleczko and Andrzej Czeczot (no, all Polish men are not called Andrzej), are quite famous (or were, as Czeczot died in 2012). Their work is published daily or weekly, it usually refers to current events, and features generic, unnamed characters. It's often quite brilliant.

One of my favorite Mleczko drawings in the "Polityka" magazine was one of a lizard stepping out of a human suit with the Warsaw government buildings in the background: "Trying to take over this place was a *huge* mistake," the reptilian says 🤣

The European go-to for tool-less furniture is Ikea. I don't buy their products though because the quality is usually terrible.

The song from the link is inaccessible in my location - probably because of copyright laws, which are better protected than human rights these days... Late-stage capitalism, eh?

@Andrzej

What you’re describing sounds like what we call “editorial cartoons” here — commentary on current events, usually political ones. They can be very funny. 

I’ve only been in an IKEA store twice. Both times, the layout drove me nuts and I couldn’t wait to get out. And now I live hundreds of miles from the nearest IKEA. 

Sorry the music link didn’t work. If you’re interested, search for Robert Earl Keen “The Little Things.” He’s a singer-songwriter from Texas with a great sense of humor.

@Eric Hougland

Ikea is ubiquitous in Poland: Warsaw has not one but two of their megastores, and they are always crowded with shoppers. Ikea's appeal is that you can get all the stuff you need for your home in one place - furniture, cutlery, potted plants, lighting, rugs, etc., etc. They also have a wide selection of individual types of items (40 different sofas, 60 chairs, etc.), so most people will find what they are looking for there - in the end, anyway, as navigating the place is nightmare when you want a specific thing (there are floorplans, and you can take shortcuts, but it's still quite inconvenient). For people who want to fill two (or five) huge shopping carts with a whole selection of household items, it is perfect.

Most Polish homes feature loads of Ikea stuff. Much of it is locally made, too (Poland is a furniture manufacturing powerhouse), which keeps costs low.

At this stage in life I prefer high quality, designer furniture though (new or vintage) so I avoid Ikea - but I shopped there gladly 15 or 20 years ago, when I was not as privileged as I am now.

That song... I'm so glad my life with my wife is nothing like that :D

BTW, I think I really do need that break from these puzzles I've been hinting at recently. Today's theme seems to have sparked joy in everybody, and I was curmudgeonly annoyed by it... For the past week or two that feeling has been my personal theme of solving NYT puzzles. It's not them, it's me, it seems.

@Andrzej

Oh, please don't go. I love your comments, and I know others do, too.

@Times Rita

That review is spot on (IMO).

@Andrzej

Sorry, I have to disagree on at least 1 point. 

Rex complains that it was very hard "for those of us who solve Downs-only", and that's simply not a fair comment on a puzzle. 

Solving Downs-only is something you might choose to do (emphasis on YOU and CHOOSE) to increase the difficulty, but if that makes it "almost too much", that's on you, not the constructor or the puzzle.

@Andrzej HONEYDO stumped me as well; I got it from crosses but looked at it a long time, thinking “surely there’s no way that’s a real thing?”. I hadn’t heard of a Honey-Do list before this puzzle and now I wish I still hadn’t!
@Times Rita Bet this "Parker" fella's a lot of fun at parties 🙄

@Andrzej

Polish IKEAs sound like the ones I’ve been in. I hate stores with a maze-like layout. 

We’re fortunate enough to have left our cheap furniture days mostly in the distant past. We did move a crappy assemble-it-yourself desk, but we found a vintage one online that looks so much better. And the woman who we gave our old desk to seemed happy to get it. 

I hope you stick around here. And I hope whatever source of stress you’re dealing with resolves itself quickly and in a positive way.

@Andrzej

I hope the source of your stress eased up quickly!

Stress can really taint everything.

Take a break from the crosswords if it helps you but know that you add a lot to the community and your opinions are always welcomed and often lead to robust interactions and new ways of seeing things. You are appreciated by many of us!

@Andrzej

I think I'm having the same sort of ennui that you're hinting at having.

There's a great line from one of my favorite "guilty pleasure" rock group's songs, the Carpenters.

"What I've got they used to call the blues."

Astoundingly perfect line.

Anyway, I hope to "see" you on the other side.  Take care.

@Francis

Not sure why the Carpenters were a "guilty pleasure".  Karen was The Voice, Richard was the Genius.

The pair were one of the first of a whole slew of early 70s soft rock acts that most of my cohort listened to:  Carole King (as an artist), James Taylor, the Eagles, etc.

Not to say that these acts were carbon copies, but the Carpenters were a bridge from the psychedelic 60s to a more mellow sound.

What a shame that Karen's health issues and subsequent death put an end to such a great duo.

@Steve L

I'm so glad to hear you say that.  I was just bowled over by the luxurious sound of the Carpenters, but they were absolutely in the "bubble gum" category.

But Karen, with her low, devastatingly sexy voice, just settled in my mind like a kitten on my lap.

I loved all the others you named, too.  

That's for making me feel less guilty!

@Megan

I agree. On first pass through I initially thought “sheesh, bit tough for a Monday” but after getting some crosses everything fell into place nicely. Exactly how a clever crossword should be.

@Megan

Seems to me an irreligious pun...

@Steve L

Also disgusting.

@who's that girl

I enjoyed it.

@Megan

And now, none of us will be able to say the Lord's Prayer with a straight face, either.  😀
@Megan......." but deliver it to under the desk."
@Rachel how did you think it was written?

@Oikofuge

In the Clue game we had when I was a kid 50+ years ago, the “lead pipe”  was a short piece of solder. Ours eventually broke because we kept bending it. 

One thing that irked me about Clue even as a young kid: I understood how fatal wounds from a wrench or a lead pipe might look alike, but how could one not tell that Mr. Boddy had been stabbed, shot or strangled with a rope? (I know there was a sixth weapon, but I don’t remember what it was.)

It wasn’t until I was in Radio-TV-Film school many years later that I learned the term “willing suspension of disbelief.”

Mean Old Lady,

Liquid puddles in April. Nice.

@Mean Old Lady
Glad you brought this up. Until I moved to the low country about five or so years ago, I had never heard of “yellow season”. It’s really a thing and your description of explosions of yellow from the Southern pines is spot on!  Most Northerners have never heard of our “love bugs” either…a unique Spring Southeastern phenomenon (check it out in Wiki…)

@Mean Old Lady

That pine pollen comes from loblolly pines. They're grown for lumber in the South, so we have a lot of them. They have no natural pollinators (insects, whatever) so they overcome that by just broadcasting huge quantities of pollen into the wind. And yeah, seeing one hit by a sudden gust is impressive.

Fortunately, the large size of the individual particles of their pollen means they don't provoke hay fever, which is why you can actually be in the South during springtime and not die.

In the state of Georgia, most of those pines are in the southern half of the state, but as far north as Atlanta you still sometimes have to clear all the pine pollen off your car glass before you can drive.

@Mean Old Lady
Next February, try acupuncture for allergies.  It’s amazing relief.

@Louise
I don't think my reactions are actually "allergies."  This amount of pollen bothers everybody, it seems like.  (I have a lot of allergies--insects, medications, foods-- so now I wonder if there is some solution other than EpiPens and eternal vigilance....

@Mean Old Lady
It’s been like that here in the Sierra foothills of California too. Crazy long allergy season showing no signs of ending.

@Mean Old Lady
Didn’t you at one time live in Arkansas? My understanding is that the loblolly pine is their State tree, while the Southern Magnolia is the Mississippi State tree. Alabama has its Longleaf pine (another “yellow pine”), while NC just left it at “Pine”, not to give preference to any of the eight species they have there. We of course went with the Palmetto…

@Mean Old Lady

I like when a sudden gust hits one of those pines just right, and a greenish-yellow cloud, still in roughly the shape of the tree, separated from it and drifts off to one side. It looks like the tree's ghost has departed from its body.

@max

When I moved from the west to upstate NY for a couple of years back in the 20-teens I was delighted by all the popular brands that I had never heard of: in the food aisles Utz and Herrs potato chips (each with an Old Bay seasoning variety, another uniquely east coast product), Edy's ice cream; store chains Wegman's (groceries), Wawa (convenience and gas), and Hess (gas station, now rebranded as Speedway, although they still sell their annual Hess Toy Trucks each Christmas, a 60-year tradition). Although I'm back in the Pacific NW  exposure to these names and others have served me well since I began doing the NYT XW during the trump flu pandemic. My wife and I really enjoyed our stay in the Finger Lakes district for this and many other reasons. The diversity of the US is to be celebrated and enjoyed.
